abstract.text: Manage background sessions and tasks.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Apps on watchOS primarily run in the foreground to limit the impact on system resources. However, sometimes an app needs to perform an action when it’s not the foreground app. For a limited number of cases, watchOS provides options for running in the background.
When the system launches your app in the background, you can:
Handle background notifications from local or remote notifications with a
delegate. For more information, see
Receive push notifications to update your app’s complications with a
delegate. For more information, see

content.text: Schedule and handle background refresh tasks

inlineContent.text: A watchOS app uses a
background refresh task
to perform work in the background. If your app requires background operations, use one of the following techniques to respond to the task:
Add a
modifier to respond to the background task in your SwiftUI scene.
Implement your app delegate’s
method to receive and respond to the task. You need to call the task’s
method to indicate that you’re done.
In both cases, the system launches your app and gives it a few seconds of background execution time to perform the task. Complete the background task as quickly as possible. For more information, see

Apps that support workouts, audio playback, or location updates can continue to run in the background until the current session ends. Your app must enable the appropriate background mode in your project’s capabilities, and then start the session while your app is running in the foreground.
Use an
object to start and stop workouts. For more information, see
Use the
class to play extended audio files in the background. For more information, see
Use a
object to start a continuous background location session. For more information, see
Extended runtime sessions give your app additional time to run while the session is active. Extended runtime sessions provide support for the following session types:
Self care
Mindfulness
Physical therapy
Smart alarm

Extended runtime sessions let the app continue to communicate with a Bluetooth device, process data, or play sounds or haptics, even after the watch’s screen turns off. While most extended runtime sessions run your app as the frontmost app, some sessions run your app in the background. Select a session type based on the app’s intended use — not based on the features that the session provides.
For more information, see

abstract.text: An object that communicates to the system how you intend to use audio in your app.
Services provided by an app that require it to run in the background.
The services a watchOS app provides that require it to continue running in the background.
The object you use to start and stop the delivery of location-related events to your app.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the app receives location updates when running in the background.
A session that tracks the user’s workout on Apple Watch.
Track a workout on Apple Watch.
Respond to push notifications related to your app’s complications, file providers, and VoIP services.
The methods that you use to handle incoming PushKit notifications and registration events.
Runs the specified action when the system provides a background task.
An interface for processing incoming notifications and responding to notification actions.
Respond to user interactions with the system’s notification interfaces, including handling your app’s custom actions.
Build watchOS apps that use features the app delegate monitors or controls, such as background tasks and extended runtime sessions.
Tells the delegate that the app has received one or more background tasks.
A task that updates your app’s state in the background.
A task for handling timely Bluetooth alerts in the background.
A session that continues to run your app after the user has stopped interacting.
A background task used to update your app after a SiriKit intent runs.
The abstract superclass for WatchKit’s background task classes.
Marks the task as complete and indicates whether the system should take a new snapshot of the app.
A background task used to periodically donate relevant Siri shortcuts.
A background task used to update your app’s user interface in preparation for a snapshot.
A task that responds to background URL sessions.
A background task used to receive background updates from the Watch Connectivity framework.
Enable the background mode for audio, location updates, remote notifications, or workouts.
Keep your complications up-to-date by reading values from a Bluetooth peripheral while your app is running in the background.

doc://com.apple.watchkit/documentation/W.title: Interacting with Bluetooth peripherals during background app refresh

abstract.text: Receive and respond to life-cycle notifications.
Enable background audio in your app to provide a seamless playback experience.
Provide a timely, accurate snapshot of your app by using snapshot background tasks.

doc://com.apple.watchkit/documentation/W.title: Preparing to take your watchOS app’s snapshot

abstract.text: Handle scheduled update tasks in the background, and respond to background system interactions including Siri intents and incoming Bluetooth messages.
Create an extended runtime session that continues running your app after the user stops interacting with it.
